5. Discussion
Based on field and remote sensing data, we infer that the geographic restriction of the Santa Cruz Sequence is due to tectonic preservation of a structural block. After deposition, the block currently bearing this sequence was lowered in the Vena?ncio Aires- Santa Cruz region, while in the adjacent, uplifted blocks this sequence was removed by erosion (Fig. 11). Another possibility is that the deposition of the Santa Cruz Sequence is local, within a restricted half-graben that controlled and isolated the sequence. Considering the proposed models for Santa Maria Supersequence in the literature, the first hypothesis is the most likely to have occurred.
In the Ischigualasto Basin from Argentina, the deposits placed between the Cha~nares and Ischigualasto Formations, which temporally would correspond to the deposition of the Santa Cruz Sequence, are lucstrine beds forming during a synrift phase (Ischichuca/Los Rastros Formations). It suggests that the active tectonics along the Andean ridge could control the deposition of the Santa Cruz Sequence. Zerfass et al. (2005) characterize three rifting phases responsible for the deposition of the sequences within the Santa Maria Supersequence. Any of these tectonic movements could have uplifted the blocks adjacent to the Santa Cruz Sequence, leading to preservation of the Santa Cruz Sequence in the lower block. nta Cruz Sequence; PS: Pinheiros-Chiniqu?a Sequence; CS: Candel?aria Sequence.
B.L.D. Horn et al. / Journal of South American Earth Sciences 55 (2014) 123e132132 6. Conclusions
The integration of satellite image analysis and field work (sedimentological, structural and paleontological information) allowed the interpretation that the Santacruzodon AZ is not only a biostratigraphic division, but also a stratigraphic sequence that represents a time slice preserved probably by tectonic movement. It is possible that other sequences could be further subdivided, and/or that other sequences could have been tectonically preserved. As the vertebrate fossils are the only tool for intra- and intercontinental correlations in the Triassic of Gondwana, the identified sequence adds important data to the depositional context of the Santa Maria Supersequence.
Sequence names used in Zerfass et al. (2003) have to be changed to better accommodate the new sequence proposed in this work, as well as possible future subdivisions in the Santa Maria Supersequence.
The recognition that some sequences occur in tectonically- controlled, restricted areas shows the importance of tectonic movements in sedimentation and/or preservation of stratigraphic units in Southern Brazil. Hence it is imperative that additional, detailed structural studies are carried out in the Paran?a Basin.

KEYWORDS 24
ephemeral rivers; massive sandstones; Upper Triassic; Candelária Sequence; Paraná Basin 25
ABSTRACT 26
Seasonally ephemeral rivers display a wide range of upper- and lower-flow regime structures due to 27
great flow-speed changes during the floods. The development of flow structures in these setting are yet 28
to be understood, especially in the formation of thick, massive sandstones. The Upper Triassic was 29
marked by great seasonal variations on climate, yet there is no documentation of river systems with 30
seasonal characteristics in Southern Gondwana. This work aims to characterize a seasonally-affected 31
alluvial system from the Upper Triassic of the Paraná Basin. The characteristics of the deposits are 32
discussed in terms of depositional processes through comparison with similar deposits in the literature, 33
flow characteristics and depositional signatures compared with flume experiments. The alluvial system 34
was divided in four facies associations: (1) channels with variable fill, characterized by low w/t ratio, 35
sheet-like bodies, scour-and-fill structures with upper- and lower-flow regime bedforms; (2) channels 36
with massive fill, characterized by low w/t ratio, sheet-like bodies, scour-and-fill structures with 37
massive sandstones; (3) proximal sheetfloods, characterized by moderate w/t ratio, sheet-like bodies 38
with upper- and lower-flow regime bedforms and (4) distal sheetfloods, characterized by high w/t 39
ratio, sheet-like bodies with lower-flow regime bedforms. Evidence for the seasonal reactivation of the 40
riverine system includes the absence of well-developed macroforms, in-channel mudstones, thick 41
intraformational conglomerates, and the occurrence of well- and poorly-preserved vertebrate bones in 42
the same beds. The predominantly massive sandstones is interpreted as collapse of the viscous lower 43
portion of a hyperconcentrated flow during abrupt changes in flow speed, caused by de-confinement 44
or channel avulsion, whereas turbulent portions of the flow formed the upper- and lower-flow regime 45
bedforms after the deposition of the massive layers. The upper portion of the Candelária Sequence 46
records a good example of strongly seasonal alluvial systems, where the predominance of massive 47
sandstones is a particular characteristic. 48
49
INTRODUCTION 50
There is a wide variability of flow velocities, discharge, sediment load and transport mechanisms that 51
influences the nature of sheetflow deposits (Fisher et al 2007), and in the ancient and modern record, a 52
variety of upper- and lower-flow regime structures are observed (Tunbridge, 1981, Olsen 1987, Fisher 53
et al. 2007, Fisher et al 2008). How these factors interact and contribute to the generation of 54
sheetfloods and feeder-channel deposits is still object of study through experimental work. 55
Modern rivers with discharge variations are common in regions with subtropical climate or a 56
monsoonal regime, where more than 80-90% of precipitation falls during summer. The intense rainfall 57
causes high magnitude floods (Plink-Björklund, 2015). The high fluctuation in precipitation during the 58
year forces the formation of ephemeral rivers that are subject to variations in discharge, and 59
consequently, depositional processes. 60
Experimental modeling and paleoclimatic sedimentologic proxies indicate that the Upper Triassic was 61
marked by a maximum expression of the monsoonal circulation (Robinson, 1973; Wang, 2009 apud 62
Preto, 2010) that caused extreme climate cross Pangea. Extensive dry periods, punctuated by brief wet 63
periods, were common in the Upper Triassic (Sellwood and Valdez, 2006; Holz, 2015) and certainly 64
exerted large influence on fluvial styles. Still, there is no record of seasonally-affected rivers in 65
Southern Gondwana Triassic. 66
The record of sedimentary structures in upper-flow regime has increased in the past few years, but it is 67
still difficult to apply experimental data to the rock record because of the many uncontrolled variables 68
on natural sedimentary systems. Lately, some authors (e.g. Alexander el al 2001, Cartigny et al. 2013, 69
Sumner et al. 2009) used flume experiments to gather data on the formation of upper-flow regime 70
structures in deep-water, turbidite settings. So far there has been little experimental data, if any, on 71
upper-flow regime structures developed in continental settings, especially in respect to the formation 72
of thick, massive sandstones. 73
In this work, the study of Upper Triassic, continental deposits of the Paraná Basin aimed at the 74
description of facies and architecture of fluvial sediments formed under semi-arid climate, 75
characteristic of monsoon -affected alluvial systems. Characteristics of sheetflood and channel 76
deposits are discussed in terms of depositional processes through comparison with other similar 77
deposits in the literature, as well as flow characteristics and the depositional signatures compared with 78
flume experiments. 79
GEOLOGICAL SETTING 80
The Paraná Basin is a large, NE-SW-elongated intracratonic basin in South America, approximately 81
1750 km long and 900 km wide, with a surface area of approximately 1,700,000 km 2 in Paraguay, 82
Uruguay, Argentina and Brazil (Fig. 1 ). This basin evolved during the Paleozoic and Mesozoic, 83
comprising a sedimentary package deposited between the Late Ordovician and the Late Cretaceous. 84
FIGURE 1 85
Milani and Ramos (1998) recognized six second-order stratigraphic sequences, and the Triassic rocks 86
correspond to Gondwana II Sequence (Anisian-Norian). Although the Paraná is an intracratonic basin, 87
the preservation of Triassic deposits in the Paraná Basin is local and probably related with 88
transtensional stresses caused by tectonic events on the Gondwanides active margin. These created 89
extensional rifts that favored the sedimentation of Triassic rocks (Zerfass et al. 2004) 90
The sequence stratigraphic framework proposed by Zerfass (2003) divides the Mesozoic succession of 91
the Middle-Upper Triassic succession (Santa Maria Supersequence) of the Paraná Basin in Rio Grande 92
do Sul State in three third-order sequences (Sequences I, II and III). Lately, Horn et al. (2014) 93
included a forth sequence (Santa Cruz Sequence, Ladinian) and changed the names of the previously 94
established third-order sequences I, II and III to Pinheiros-Chiniquá (Anysian-Ladinian), Candelária 95
(Carnian) and Mata (Rhaetic) (Fig. 2 ). The Santa Maria Supersequence is equivalent to the Triassic 96
Gondwana II Supersequence of Milani and Ramos (1998), which occurs only in southern Brazil. 97
Figure 2 98
The studied rocks belong to the upper Candelária Sequence, cropping out in the central portion of Rio 99
Grande do Sul State, between the cities of Candelária and Mata (Fig. 1). 100
FACIES ANALYSIS 101
Facies analysis was based on the description of 31 outcrops (Fig. 1), with the construction of 102
lithological logs at 1:50 scale and the systematic measurement of paleocurrents. Facies description 103
included color, grain size, roundness, sorting and grain composition, bed geometry, sedimentary 104
structures and fossil content. Eight lithofacies were recognized in the upper Candelária Sequence, 105
summarized in Table 1. Facies classification was based on an adaptation to the code proposed by Miall 106
(1985). 107
The upper Candelária Sequence is dominantly composed of reddish, very fine to fine sandstones, with 108
subordinate intraformational conglomerates and mudrocks. The sandstones are well-sorted and mostly 109
massive (Sm), but locally laminated and cross-stratified sandstones may occur (Sl, Sgh, St or Sr). The 110
sandstones are commonly amalgamated, or separated by reddish mudstones and siltstones, laminated 111
(Fl) or massive (Fm).The intraformational conglomerates (Gi) are formed by mud intraclasts, 0.5-20 112
cm across, immersed in a fine sand matrix. 113
TABLE 1 114
Intraformational conglomerates (Gi) 115
The intraformational conglomerates (Gi) consist of matrix-supported conglomerates, with fine sand 116
matrix and granule- to cobble-sized mud intraclasts. There are two distinct clast grain sizes, pebble-117
dominated andgranule- dominated. (Fig. 3A). In addition to the mud intraclasts, the pebble-dominated 118
conglomerates contain carbonate clasts. This facies occurs mainly as centimetric layers at the base of 119
massive and gradational planar-laminated sandstones (Sm and Sgh), but it may also occur in metric, 120
continuous or discontinuous beds overlying fine-grained facies (Fm and Fl). 121
The granule-dominated conglomerates are interpreted as curled-up and broken mud cracks 122
incorporated to flows (Glennie, 1970). Pebble-dominated conglomerates are interpreted as product of 123
deposition of eroded or slumped overbanks incorporated to the bottom of hyperconcentred flows 124
(Coleman, 1969), as occurring in some modern monsoonal river settings (Singh et al. 1993; Gohain 125
and Parkash, 1990). Carbonate clasts derive from overbank areas with carbonate soils, what reinforces 126
the interpretation of collapsed banks. 127
Massive sandstones (Sm) 128
They comprise reddish, very fine- to fine-grained sandstones, massive, locally with dispersed, granule-129
sized mud intraclasts. The Sm facies can occur alone, arranged in multistory sandstone bodies up to 50 130
cm thick, with common cut-and-fill structures, or associated with Sgh, Sr and Gi facies. Locally the 131
Sm facies appears to grade upward to incipient horizontally-stratified sandstones (Fig. 3B). 132
This facies is interpreted as the result of deposition from a flux heavy-laden in sediments, what may 133
have prevented the development of tractive structures, thus generating massive sandstones (Baker et 134
al., 1993; Fisher et al., 2007) (see below). The incipient stratification is the result of high depositional 135
rates during deposition (Sumner et al., 2009; Arnott, 2012).The massive sandstones (Sm) have been 136
interpreted by previous workers as delta front deposits, with obliteration of sedimentary structures 137
caused by fluidization (Faccini, 2000), or resulting from bar collapse (Rupert and Schultz, 2004) The 138
latter process cannot appropriately explain the abundance of this facies, since frequent and voluminous 139
bar collapses are improbable. 140
Gradational planar-laminated sandstones (Sgh) 141
They comprise reddish, fine-grained sandstones with gradational planar lamination (Fig. 3C), at places 142
with coarse sand-sized mud clasts along the stratification. This stratification is characterized by multi-143
millimeter (5-8mm) thick laminations (Fig. 3E). The Sgh facies occurs mainly associated with Sm, but 144
may also occur with St, Sl, Sr and Fl facies (Fig. 3C, D, E), arranged in multistory sandstone bodies or 145
sheet-like, laterally extensive bodies. 146
This facies was interpreted as planar-bedded deposits originated via upper flow regime. This facies is 147
described as a type of Froude transcritical to supercritical structure (FTSS), formed between Fr ~7 to 148
Fr=1 (Fielding, 2006; Allen et al, 2014). The thick lamination is evidence of high deposition rates, in 149
which high aggradation caused by sediment fallout competes with unidirectional flow and thickens the 150
lamination (North and Taylor, 1996; Billi, 2007). 151
Trough cross-bedded sandstones (St) 152
This facies comprises reddish, fine- to medium-grained sandstones, with trough- cross stratification, 153
locally with coarse sand-sized mud clasts along the stratification (Fig. 3D). The St facies is commonly 154
associated with Sgh, Sl, Sr and Fl facies, arranged in lenticular sandstone bodies with 0.5 to 1m thick. 155
The trough cross-stratified sandstones (St) are interpreted as deposition under lower flow regime in 156
turbulent stages during flow, generating asymmetric, sinuous dunes (Miall, 1977; Harms et al., 1982; 157
Collinson et al., 2006). 158
Sandstones with low-angle cross stratification (Sl) 159
This facies consists of reddish, fine sandstones, with low-angle cross stratification and occurs 160
exclusively in association with Sgh facies (Fig. 3C). This is a very uncommon facies, occurring in 161
sheet-like beds and bed tops, only in the proximal sheetflood facies association. 162
The low-angle cross-stratified sandstones are interpreted as humpback or washed-out dunes on the 163
transition between subcritical and supercritical flows (Harms et al., 1982; Bridge and Best, 1988), in 164
conditions of rapid variation of flux velocities and depth. 165
Ripple-laminated sandstones (Sr) 166
They comprise reddish, fine to very fine sandstones, with current ripple cross-lamination. This facies 167
form sets about 8 cm thick of subcritical to critical climbing ripples usually in the same bed, where the 168
climbing angle varies upward from subcritical to critical. It occurs as tabular beds overlying Sgh or St 169
facies (Fig. 3E). 170
Unidirectional, subcritical ripples are interpreted as a product of subaqueous ripple migration under 171
unidirectional, lower flow regime (Allen, 1963; Miall, 1977; 1996), preferentially after the peak 172
flooding in slowly decreasing water flow. Sandstones with critical ripples are interpreted as formed 173
with the rapid decline of flood waters, from upper to lower flow regime conditions in the final stages 174
of waning flows (McKee, 1967; Fisher et al. 2008). 175
Laminated mudstones (Fl) 176
They are composed of red, laminated mudstones that occur as mud drapes, a few millimeters thick, on 177
top of sandstone beds, or as centimetric to decimetric lenticular layers (Fig. 3F). The thicker layers are 178
intercalated with sandstone beds, and are mottled and with carbonate nodules. 179
The laminated mudstones are interpreted as resulting from suspension settling from standing waters in 180
the final stages of ephemeral floods, even as in-channel, mud deposits (Williams, 1971; Tunbridge, 181
1981). The presence of mud layers in channel settings is characteristic of seasonal rivers and is linked 182
with rapid waning of high-magnitude flows (Plink-Bjöklund, 2015). Calcretes and mottles indicate 183
pedogenetic alterations that suggest a significant time interval between flooding events. 184
Massive mudstones (Fm) 185
This facies is composed of red, massive mudstones that occur as decimetric to metric continuous 186
layers, commonly with carbonate nodules and root marks. Fm facies occurs only in the distal 187
sheetflood facies association. 188
The massive mudstones are interpreted as resulting from suspension settling in overbank areas, later 189
modified by pedogenetic processes, with post-depositional reddening under oxidizing conditions 190
(Miall, 1977; 1990; Foix et al, 2013). The carbonate nodules indicate pedogenetic alteration on 191
deposits under dry climates. 192

FACIES ASSOCIATIONS 194
The lithofacies identified in the upper Candelária Sequence were genetically grouped in four facies 195
associations: (1) massive channel fill, (2) variable-flow channel fill (3) proximal sheetfloods, and (4) 196
distal sheetfloods. The abundance of facies on each facies association is shown on figure 4. 197
FIGURE 4 198
Paleocurrent analysis was impaired by the dominance of massive sandstones in the studied succession. 199
The few paleocurrent measurements obtained in the variable-flow channel fill and proximal sheetflood 200
facies associations show paleoflow to N-NE (Fig.5). 201
FIGURE 5 202
Channels 203
In this work, clear differences in the channel-fill deposits were detected. Therefore, the channel 204
deposits were split in two facies associations: variable-flow channel fill and massive channel fill. It 205
was utilized de concept of “flood units”, proposed by Plink- Björklund (2015). Flood units are 206
depositional units bounded by erosion surfaces, or with an erosion surface below and a mud drape 207
above. This concept is very similar “flood events” or “floods” utilized by other authors, such as Miall 208
(2006) and Allen et al. (2014). 209
Variable-flow channel fill 210
These facies association consists of laterally extensive, sheet-like sandstone beds bounded by cut-and-211
fill structures below and mud drapes above. The bases of channels are usually scoured, with up to 1 m 212
of relief, often overlying the mudstones in the lower Candelária Sequence. The channel-fill deposits 213
are composed of several facies, such as Gi, Sm, Sgh, St, Sr and Fl (Table 2), vertically stacked in this 214
succession from base to top, thus indicating a decelerating flow (Mckee, 1967; Tunbridge, 1981; 215
Fisher et al. 2007) (Fig. 6A, B, C). Locally these channel-fill deposits resemble macroforms with 216
accretion surfaces, with the Gi-Sm-Sgh succession in sloping lenticular beds, overlain by a centimetric 217
Fl layer (Fig. 6D, E). The preservation of mud drapes or layers depends on the amount of scouring 218
caused by the next flood, so the flood units may be bounded at bottom and top by erosive surfaces. 219
Amalgamated channels may occur but they are not common, since mud drapes, or layers of Fm or Fl, 220
usually cap each flood unit. In this facies association the intraformational conglomerates are coarser 221
(pebble-dominated) than the ones found in the massive channel fill facies association (Fig. 6 B, C). 222
The erosional-based, sheet-like sandstone beds argue for deposition on poorly channelized fluvial 223
channels. The absence of developed macroforms and abundance of FTSS suggests a seasonally 224
variable discharge (Fielding et al., 2009; Allen et al. 2011) and deposition mainly on discharge peak. 225
The presence of unidirectional lower flow regime bedforms indicates a less rapid transition of the flow 226
strength during the peak discharge (Plink- Björklund, 2015). The low rate of preservation of these 227
dunes is attributed to highly erosive flow power, which erodes the majority of previous channel fill. 228
FIGURE 6 229
Massive channel fill 230
This facies association consists of laterally extensive, sheet-like sandstone beds bounded by cut-and-231
fill structures below and above. The massive sandstones (Sm) are dominant in this facies association. 232
The channel bases are scoured, with up to 0.25 m of relief, infilled by stacked beds of massive 233
sandstones (Sm), sometimes with Sgh at the top, organized in sandbodies 1-2 m wide and 0.5 m high 234
(Fig. 7A, C). The sandstone bodies are mainly amalgamates, and where the basal Gi facies is not 235
present, it is difficult to delimit flood units. The Gi facies is dominated by very coarse sand- to 236
granule-sized clasts (Fig. 7B). 237
The amalgamated, erosive based sheet-like sandstones indicates deposition by a poorly channelized 238
river. The absence of macroforms and bedforms and the predominance of massive sandstones indicate 239
deposition by a heavy-laden flow with a rapid waning stage and stop, avoiding reworking by 240
consequent discharges. Also, thin mud layers and abundant mud chips inside the massive sandstone 241
shows a high flow erosive power that eroded the previously deposited sand and reworked the mud 242
chips and sand in new deposits. 243
FIGURE 7 244
Despite the differences in infilling between the channel associations, some features are found on both. 245
The absence of macroforms, the abundance of FTSS, in-channel mudstones and sheet-like deposits 246
occurs as the striking characteristics for these rivers. Froude transcritical to supercritical structures are 247
generally thought to have a low preservation potential because the bedforms that are constructed 248
during transcritical to supercritical flow conditions are generally reworked into subcritical bedforms 249
during the waning flow stage (Allen et al. 2014 apud Jones, 1977; Southard and Boguchwal, 1990). 250
The preservation of FTSS in fluvial environments requires either shallow flows that can approach or 251
exceed Froude numbers of unity (e.g. Langford & Bracken, 1987), or extremely variable discharge 252
events in which rapid aggradation and flow deceleration preclude reworking into subcritical bedforms 253
(McKee et al., 1967; Sneh, 1983; Alexander & Fielding, 1997). Fluvial deposits that preserve an 254
abundance of FTSS structures have traditionally been restricted to arid alluvial fan systems (Blair & 255
McPherson, 1994) and ephemeral rivers (Tunbridge, 1981; Dreyer, 1993; North & Taylor, 1996). The 256
sheet-like geometry indicates a wide and shallow channel, what explains the preservation of these 257
structures. Besides, the lack of macroforms and scarcity of bedforms indicates rapid flow deceleration, 258
so both conditions for FTSS preservation are achieved in this system. 259
Sheetfloods 260
Sheetflood deposits were separated in distal and proximal sheetfloods, based on facies geometry and 261
thickness to estimate the degree of proximity with the channel. Proximal sheetflood deposits are 262
characterized by thicker sandstone packages, with tabular geometry and facies succession typical of 263
waning flows. The sandstone bodies vary between 0.5 and 1m thick and are always capped by 264
centimetric to decimetric mud drapes (Fig. 8). Distal sheetflood deposits are characterized by tabular, 265
0.1-0.2 m thick sandbodies, capped by centimetric mud drapes (Fig. 9). Massive or laminated 266
sandstones (Sm and Sgh) are common facies in both sheetflood facies associations. 267
Proximal sheetfloods 268
This facies association is formed by Sm, Sgh, Sr, St, Sl, Fm and Fl facies. The sandstone facies 269
comprise reddish, very fine- to fine-grained sandstones, arranged in sheet-like sandstone bodies (0.5-270
1m thick) (Table 2) (Fig. 8A, B, C). Sandstone facies (Sm, Sgh, St, Sl and Sr) are vertically stacked in 271
this succession, from base to top. 272
This association is interpreted as frontal and/or lateral channel splays. The lack of well-developed, 273
cross-laminated successions above the parallel-laminated sandstones points to a rapidly waning flow 274
with no low-stage reactivation of the sediment (Tunbridge, 1981). Depressions within the channels or 275
spread-outs of sheetfloods may generate temporary ponds where mud can deposit, generating the Fm 276
or Fl facies (Fisher et al. 2008). 277
FIGURE 8 278
Distal sheetfloods 279
This facies association is formed by the Sm, Sgh, Sr and Fm facies. The main distinction in relation to 280
the proximal sheetflood facies association is the higher W/T ratio and the absence of St and Sl facies 281
(Table 2) (Fig. 9A). The dominant, massive sandstones (Sm) are less than 0.2 m thick and laterally 282
extensive. The mudstones (Fm) are very thin, comprising only millimetric mud drapes between 283
sandstone layers (Fig. 9 B, C, D). 284
FIGURE 9 285
This facies association is interpreted as unconfined sheetflood deposits reaching the most distal 286
portions in the floodplain. The conspicuous presence of mud drapes attest to the ephemeral nature of 287
the flows (Tunbridge, 1981; Fisher et al. 2007). Rare Fm tabular layers are intercalated with distal 288
sheetflood deposits, representing the overbank deposits. These show features indicative of pedogenetic 289
alteration, such as carbonate concretions and root marks. 290

The lack of extensive and/or abundant outcrops precluded the determination of the lateral variation 292

The dominance of massive sandstones (Sm) in the four facies associations is peculiar for fluvial 294
deposits, and thus these deposits have been interpreted as deltaic by former workers (Faccini, 2000; 295
Zerfass et al. 2003, Da Rosa, 2014). However, massive sandstones (Sm) can be formed in 296
hyperconcentrated flows whenever the frequency and intensity of precipitation provides enough 297
suspended sediments. Flume experiments carried out by Cartigny (2013) and Sumner (2009) modeled 298
high-concentration and high-velocity streams. According to these works, the high proportion of 299
suspended sediment (up to 10%) causes flow stratification in two or three layers. The most basal layer 300
is a high-concentration moving layer that is non-turbulent and in which particle movement is hindered 301
by the presence of other particles; the top layer of the flow displays a turbulent suspension (Sumner, 302
2009). The experiments showed that, if the flow is abruptly decelerated (from 3.5 m.s -1
to zero below 303
120 s), the basal layer collapses and the high rate of sediment fallout suppresses sedimentary 304
structures. These fluxes have erosive power due to the high flux velocity. 305
The massive sandstones (Sm) in the upper Candelária Sequence were interpreted here as formed in the 306
basal layer of fluvial flows through deceleration and suspension-load fallout. The velocity of the flow 307
utilized in experimental work (3.5 m.s -1
; Sumner, 2009; Cartigny, 2013) is compatible with natural 308
flood events, in which velocities between 7.6 m.s -1
to 0.5 m.s -1
were registered (Fisher et al. 2007). As 309
the flux de-confines due to gradient variation, the basal layer is deposited on the channel as Sm in 310
response to abrupt deceleration (Fig. 10). The turbulent layer initially generates upper-flow flat beds or 311
transitional attenuated dunes (Sh and Sl) and, as flow deceleration proceeds, 3D dunes and ripples are 312
formed (St and Sr), until the velocity drops to approximately zero and the suspended mud content 313
settles, forming mud drapes. 314
FIGURE 10 315
Ephemeral streams do not suffer the process of armouring (Leeder, 2011), which is the accumulation 316
of a layer of immobile sediment coarser than the flux is capable to transport. Armouring occurs as a 317
perennial stream removes the finer sediment, leaving only this immobile layer, so the quantity of 318
bedload is controlled, avoiding the formation of high concentration flows (Almadeij & Diplas, 2005). 319
In intermittent flows, armouring does not occur and a large quantity of suspension material is present 320
in ephemeral streams. 321
DISCUSSION 322
Based on the facies analysis, the upper Candelária Sequence was interpreted as deposited in shallow, 323
seasonally flooded fluvial channels dominated by high-discharge, flashy flows that distally and 324
laterally expanded into unconfined sheetfloods, probably associated with changes in the gradient 325
profile and avulsion processes. The transition from channelized to unconfined causes the deceleration 326
of the flow, since flux velocity is inversely proportional to channel area (Leeder, 2011). 327
The facies geometry and spatial distribution in the variable-flow channel fill is very similar to those 328
described for ephemeral high-discharge rivers by Mckee (1967), Tunbridge (1981), Miall (1984), the 329
model “12” from Miall (1985) and the “flashy, ephemeral, sheetflood river” from Miall (1996). Facies 330
and bed geometry are similar to sheetflood deposits, hence to identify a channel fill deposit is 331
important to recognize the basal Gi facies and the scour-and-fill structures. The river system of Upper 332
Candelária Sequence is also similar to facies association A3 of Allen et al. (2014). Although variable-333
flow fill facies association is similar, the system described here is different of all these models for the 334
dominance of massive sandstone channel fill. 335
Modern examples of this type of channel occur where the total annual precipitation falls in a few 336
downpours that last from hours to a few days, whereas mean annual rainfall amounts vary, as in the 337
Sinai Peninsula and the Karoo river (Sneh, 1983; Stear, 1985). This precipitation pattern is linked with 338
intermittent dry periods that may last for a large portion of the year, or even decades (Sneh, 1983; 339
Stear, 1985; Plink- Björklund, 2015). 340
Avulsion is a very common feature in monsoonal and subtropical rivers (Plink- Björklund, 2015). 341
Shallow rivers with high bed aggradation rates suffer rapid bedform superelevaltion, what is the main 342
avulsion trigger (Sinha, 2009; Pink-Björklund, 2015). Also, large fluctuations of the river discharge 343
and the occurrence of floods serve as avulsion-triggering events (Jones and Schumm, 1999). The 344
avulsions occur during seasonal flooding and could generate sheetfloods laterally to channels, as 345
crevasse splays. Due to the lack of outcrops where the lateral variation between facies associations can 346
be traced, it is difficult to precise which sheetfloods are lateral and which are frontal to the channels. 347
Sheetflood deposits are described by several authors as terminal splays (Blair, 2000; Tooth, 1999, 348
Lang et al. 2004), but due to the lack of tractive structures and outcrops in the study area this relation 349
cannot be affirmed. Nevertheless, the succession in the upper Candelária Sequence, in terms of facies 350
geometry, sedimentary structures and grain size, is similar to the terminal splays described for the 351
Huesca and La Luna Basins of Spain by Fisher et al. (2008). The terminal splays in Spain were 352
described as low-gradient sheetflood deposits, evidenced by the fine grain size and high W/T ratio. 353
The rare laterally extensive outcrops of the upper Candelária Sequence allowed only a limited number 354
of measurements of the W/T ratio, but nonetheless those were similar to the W/T ratios reported in 355
Fisher et al. (2008), and thus were interpreted as low-gradient sheetflood deposits. Other limitation of 356
the lack of outcrops is the absence of association relationship and spatial distribution. Dominance of 357
massive-fill facies association with the common avulsions may characterize a fluvial megafan, as 358
absence of gravity flow deposits and low gradient is proven. Fluvial megafans are characterized by 359
large lateral extent (>10 4 Km²), and for lateral and vertical facies transitions. According to Leier et al. 360
(2005), there is a tendency to monsoonal and subtropical rivers to form fluvial fans, if they have large 361
enough discharge and sediment supply. However, not all seasonal river forms a fluvial fan, may 362
entering in narrow or small basins where they cannot migrate. 363
This river system may also characterize a terminal fan or terminal distributary system. In these 364
settings, the channels form splittings rather than avulsions, and are commonly linked to high 365
evaporation (Kelly and Olsen, 1993; Nichols and Fisher, 2007). Given the available dataset, the 366
system is composed of relatively fixed channels that occupy a large area. Lateral sheetfloods 367
characterize the avulsion processes, and may propitiate the formation of new channels during large 368
floods. Dominant floodplain deposits may characterize the distal sheetflood deposits, where the flow 369
disperses in a terminal splay. 370
Paleocurrent data, though scarce, indicate that sediments came from S- SW, with a source area in the 371
Sul-Riograndense Shield. This area had already been proposed as source for the sediments of the 372
Pinheiros-Chiniquá, Santa Cruz and lower Candelária Sequence by Zerfass (2000). 373
The sheet geometry of the sandstones, the absence of channel bar deposits, the abundance of upper 374
flow- and high-concentration structures, the occurrence of in-channel mud layers, along with the 375
scarcity of floodplain deposits, do not agree with the previous interpretation of a meandering river 376
system that evolved to a lacustrine delta (Faccini, 2000). In a meandering fluvial system, it would be 377
expected the presence of developed macroforms and dunes. Although the abundant massive 378
sandstones have been interpreted as resulting from fluidization or collapse of deltaic channel bars, 379
there is no evidence of sedimentary structures obliterated by fluidization (e.g. dish-and-pillar, pipes, 380
convolute bedding), and thus these sandstones were interpreted as depositionally massive. 381
The constant presence of the variable-flow channel fill facies association directly above mudstones of 382
the lower Candelária Sequence, followed by massive channel fill facies association, may imply a 383
climate change in the upper Candelária Sequence. The common preservation of mud and the presence 384
of lower-flow regime structures (e.g. St facies) in the variable-flow channel fill deposits indicate a less 385
rapid decline in flow strength, compared to the uniform channel fills of the massive-fill channel 386
deposits, indicating that some residual base flow may have remained after flood episodes, suggesting 387
wetter conditions. 388
The high degree of mixing of fossils, with distinct sizes, weathering stages and insect burrows, found 389
in the massive sandstones, verifies the hypothesis of a seasonal climate, with variable duration 390
between wet seasons. The faunal content of these rocks is mainly terrestrial vertebrates, with the 391
exception of a stereospondyl amphibian (Dias-da-Silva et al. 2009) found in distal sheetflood deposits, 392
probably the most humid area due to water accumulation following the flood events (Fig. 11). 393
FIGURE 11 394
Various authors interpret that the interior portions of Gondwana had monsoonal climate during the 395
Triassic (Parrish, 1993; Preto, 2010). However, reconstructions of the paleolatitudes for South 396
America places the Santa Maria Supersequence in higher southern latitudes that would be expected for 397
a monsoonal influence. Different lines of evidence corroborate the semi-arid climate for the Triassic in 398
the Paraná Basin (e.g. Holz & Scherer, 1998; Horn et al., 2013). Holz (2015) states that Late Triassic 399
was marked by extreme continental heat, with an increase in the number of hot days and without 400
precipitation, and an exponential rise in land surface affected by aridity. This scenario agrees with the 401
occurrence of ephemeral, high-discharge rivers described here for the upper Candelária Sequence. 402
Sellwood and Valdez (2006) modeled Mesozoic climate utilizing atmospheric circulation models. The 403
models agree with the rock record, and for southern Gondwana they propose a predominant hot and 404
arid climate with a short wet season. So, even if not under the influence of a monsoonal climate, the 405
rivers would show strong seasonal control. 406
The proposition of seasonal, sheetflood-dominated rivers in the upper Candelária Sequence is 407
compatible with the mode of occurrence of vertebrate fossils. These fossils are found in the massive 408
sandstones interpreted as channel-fill deposits. Articulated or semi-articulated fossils of dinosaurs, 409
such as Guaibasaurus candelariensis (Bonaparte et al., 1999) and three articulated dinosaurs not yet 410
identified (Temp-Müller et al., 2014), articulated or semi-articulated fossils of small vertebrates, such 411
as Riograndia guaibensis (Bonaparte et al., 2001) and Soturnia caliodon (Cisneros & Schutlz, 2003), 412
as well as disarticulated, poorly-preserved, deteriorated bones that did not allow taxonomic 413
identification, were found. Moreover, Paes (2013) found diverse insect marks and burrows on heavily-414
weathered bones from the Sm facies. According to the latter work, the development of these burrows 415
takes months to occur, what indicates seasonal deposition in the channels. According to Sinha (2009), 416
monsoonal rivers are especially prone to catastrophic flood events, possibly killing and/or burying 417
recently dead animals. The variation in bone size, degree of articulation, preservation and pre-burial 418
exposure in the same facies suggests highly variable depositional rates and periodicity within the 419
channels, with possibly long periods of non-deposition. Concomitantly, recently deceased, well-420
preserved, articulated individuals and poorly-preserved, disarticulated bones could be buried in the 421
same flood event, corroborating the hypothesis of seasonal flooding. 422
Therefore, the presence of various features characteristic of strongly seasonal and/or monsoon-affected 423
rivers (e.g. Allen et al. 2014) occur in the study area, despite the paleolatitudal configuration that is not 424
proper for monsoonal influence. As stated before, the facies associations described in this work 425
suggest that precipitation was concentrated in few, large episodes, separated by long, dry periods as 426
evidenced by vertebrate fossil taphonomy. The extreme seasonality of the Late Triassic in Southern 427
Gondwana propitiated conditions for the development of rivers very similar to those monsoon-affected 428
ones out the monsoonal influence belt. 429
CONCLUSIONS 430
1- The deposition of the upper Candelária Sequence was carried out by an ephemeral fluvial system 431
with frontal and lateral avulsions dominated by sheetfloods, under a strongly seasonal, semi-arid 432
climate, with seasonal rainfall. 433
2- The channel deposits record two distinct channel types: the basal, variable-flow channels, usually 434
overlying the lower Candelária Sequence mudstones, indicate a less concentrated seasonal flow, and 435
the top massive channels that indicate severe seasonnal precipitation and catastrophic floods with high 436
sediment load. 437
3- The dominance of massive sandstones is the result of an abrupt decrease in gradient along the 438
channel profile, as the flow is laterally or distally unconfined and spread-out in sheetfloods. The high 439
grain fallout rate associated with flow deceleration inhibits the formation of tractive structures on 440
channels. In sheetflood deposits, the more gradual deceleration allows the construction of upper- and 441
lower flow regime bedforms. 442
4-The faunal content of mostly terrestrial vertebrates and the variable degree of weathering of the 443
bones indicate that fluvial deposition occurred in conditions in which fresh carcasses could be mixed 444
with long-deceased ones, corroborating with the paleoclimatic models and the interpretation of 445
ephemeral streams, with variable time intervals between flood events. 446
5- The alluvial system recorded in the Triassic of the Paraná Basin constitutes a good example of an 447
ancient ephemeral river in southern Gondwana, with the massive channel fill deposits indicating long 448
dry periods between the high-precipitation episodes. 449

RESUMO 39
40
As rochas triássicas da Bacia do Paraná são divididas em três unidades estratigráficas formais: 41
Formações Sanga do Cabral, Santa Maria e Caturrita. Entretanto, as litologias e relações 42
estratigráficas variam das duas unidades superiores variam de acordo com o autor. Diferentes 43
idades e posições estratigráficas foram propostas para a Formação Caturrita, normalmente 44
baseados em critérios dúbios que geram confusão. Portanto, uma revisão estratigráfica se faz 45
necessária. Este trabalho visa entender as relações estratigráficas do pacote sedimentar 46
conhecido como Formação Caturrita, e baseado em compilações bibliográficas e dados de 47
campo, propor a adoção de uma nova unidade litoestratigráfica chamada Formação Botucaraí. 48
Esta unidade têm estratótipos bem expostos próximos ao Cerro Botucaraí, no município gaúcho 49
de Candelária, compostos predominantemente por arenitos maciços. Fósseis de vertebrados 50
encontrados in situ nos estratótipos indicam idade noriana para essa Formação. Seu limite 51
inferior consiste em uma paraconformidade ou discordância erosiva com os lamitos vermelhos 52
do Membro Alemoa da Formação Santa Maria. Seu limite superior pode ser uma 53
paraconformidade com a Formação Botucatu, de idade Juro-Cretácea, ou uma discordância 54
erosiva com a unidade informal, arenitos Mata, de idade Triássica Superior (?). Além disso, em 55
um afloramento, a ocorrência de camadas fluviais com plantas e conchostráceos com afinidades 56
jurássicas indica a presença de uma unidade jurássica até então desconhecida sobre a Formação 57
Botucaraí. 58

ABSTRACT 66
67
The Triassic rocks of Paraná Basin are divided in three formal stratigraphic units: Sanga do 68
Cabral, Santa Maria and Caturrita Formations. However, the lithologies and stratigraphic 69
relationships between the two upper units vary depending on the author. Different ages and 70
stratigraphic positions have been proposed to the Caturrita Formation, often based on dubious 71
criteria that led to confusion. Based on bibliographic and field data, this work aims at entangling 72
the stratigraphic relations of the sedimentary package formerly known as the Caturrita 73
Formation, proposing the adoption of a new stratigraphic unit called Botucaraí Formation, with 74
stratotypes well exposed near the Botucaraí Hill in Candelária municipality, composed 75
predominantly by massive sandstones. Vertebrate fossils found in situ in the stratotypes indicate 76
a Norian age for this Formation. Its lower boundary is an abrupt contact or erosive 77
unconformity with the red mudstones (Alemoa Member) of the Santa Maria Formation 78
(Ladinian-Carnian). Its upper boundary is either a concordant unconformity with the Juro-79
Cretaceous Botucatu Formation or an erosive unconformity with the Late Triassic (?) Mata 80
sandstones. Moreover, in one outcrop, the occurrence of fluvial layers bearing plants and 81
conchostracan with Jurassic affinities indicates the presence of a hitherto unknown Jurassic unit 82
overlying the Botucaraí Formation. 83
KEY-WORDS: Triassic; Caturrita Formation; Paraná Basin; Botucaraí Formation; 84

INTRODUCTION 90
The Brazilian Triassic rocks of the Paraná Basin are well known by the geoscientific 91
community for its diverse vertebrate faunal content, including, among others, early dinosaurs 92
and mammals. These rocks are divided in three formal units: Sanga do Cabral, Santa Maria and 93
Caturrita Formations. The latter corresponds to a series of layers that overly the Santa Maria 94
Formation and received different formal statements over time (proposed by distinct authors), 95
posing a series of conflicting information concerning its litho- and and biostratigraphic 96
frameworks that led us to undertake here a complete review. 97
Bortoluzzi (1974), while working on the surroundings of Santa Maria Municipality (Fig. 98
1), Rio Grande do Sul State, southern Brazil, described some fluvial sandstones with silicified 99
logs, placed above the red mudstones of the Santa Maria Formation at the Caturrita Hill locality, 100
as well as others occurring along the Santa Maria-Julio de Castilhos road, as comprising the 101
basal member of the Cretaceous (at that time considered as Jurassic) Botucatu Formation, being 102
these basal layers named Caturrita Member. According to that author, the basal contact of the 103
Caturrita Member with the Santa Maria Formation was an erosive unconformity with mud-chip 104
conglomerates. The described rocks were mainly trough or planar cross-stratified sandstones, 105
with silicified logs and plant remains in some outcrops. Barberena (1977) reinforced this 106
proposition claiming that the fossils described by Bortoluzzi (1974) along the Santa Maria-Julio 107
de Castilhos road were distinct from those present in the underlying Santa Maria Formation, 108
both due to differences in the paleofloristic content and the presence of several conchostracans, 109
described by Katoo (1971), which suggested a Jurassic age for the Caturrita Member. Later on, 110
Andreis et al. (1980), during a mapping project, found similar rocks - but with no fossils - near 111
Rio Pardo Municipality (Fig. 1) also overlying the typical red mudstones of the Santa Maria 112
Formation. Despite the absence of fossils in the studied area, Andreis et al. (1980) correlated 113
these layers with those included in the Caturrita Member by Bortoluzzi, 1974. Moreover, 114
Andreis et al. (1980) proposed a Triassic age for this package, rather than Jurassic, based on a 115
presumed correlation between those rocks and other ones occurring in a third locality in 116
Candelária Municipality (Fig. 1), corresponding to overlying the Santa Maria Formation but 117
containing Triassic vertebrates. Andreis et al. (1980) referred to these fossils as follows: 118
“According to our observations, the remains of Proterochampsia, Exaeretodon and Jachaleria, 119
related by Barberena (1977) for the Alemoa Member of the Santa Maria Formation should be 120
considered as pertaining to the Caturrita Formation”. In fact, the existence of those fossils and 121
their assignment to Triassic were informally known when Andreis et al. (1980) published their 122
paper, but there is no mention to them in Barberena (1977). Indeed, Jachaleria candelariensis 123
(Araújo; Gonzaga, 1980) was published in that same year, while Proterochampsa nodosa 124
appeared only two years later (Barberena, 1982), and the new cynodont from Candelaria was 125
cited as Exaeretodon sp. only in Barberena et al. (1985). Furthermore, Andreis et al. (1980) 126
changed the age (from Jurassic to Triassic) and the hierarchic status (from Caturrita Member to 127
Caturrita Formation) of that package, based also in the work of Jabur (1979), a Master´s thesis 128
for which the results formally came out only in 1985. Jabur (1979, 1985) reinterpreted the 129
euestheriids conchostracans identified by Katoo (1971) as the genus Echinestheria, indicative of 130
a Late Triassic age, hence detaching the Caturrita Member from the Botucatu Formation (J/K). 131
As a consequence, the Caturrita Member (of the Botucatu Formation) was changed into a 132
separate unit, the Caturrita Formation, occurring around Santa Maria and Candelária 133
Municipalities, characterized by a fossil content of Triassic tetrapods and fossil logs. From that 134
moment on, Andreis et al. (1982) included in the Caturrita Formation all the layers bearing 135
silicified logs that overlain the Santa Maria Formation, mainly at Mata and São Pedro do Sul 136
municipalities. However, neither the silicified logs nor any fossil vertebrates were present on 137
Rio Pardo region, where the type-section of this Formation was defined. 138
Figure 1 139
It is our belief that both the description of the Caturrita Member by Bortoluzzi (1974) 140
and the proposal of the Caturrita Formation by Andreis et al. (1980) are probably 141
misinterpretations. Field observations on the Caturrita Hill revealed that the silicified logs 142
mentioned by Bortoluzzi (1974) are not in situ, but are relicts of weathered overlying levels, 143
thus forming a lag deposit. In turn, the outcrop bearing such logs along the Santa Maria-Julio de 144
Castilhos road no longer exists, but its stratigraphic level is surely far above the Santa Maria 145
Formation. In fact, the lithologies described by Bortoluzzi (1974) at the Caturrita Hill (trough or 146
planar cross-stratified sandstones, mud-chip conglomerates) are similar to those of the Passo das 147
Tropas Member from the Santa Maria Formation. This misunderstanding is not surprising if one 148
takes into account that, at that time, the Passo das Tropas Member was defined as the basal 149
portion of the Santa Maria Formation, always occurring below the fossiliferous red mudstones. 150
Therefore, the finding of sandy-conglomeratic layers with fossil logs (absent in the Passo das 151
Tropas Member) above the red mudstones was interpreted as evidence of a new stratigraphic 152
unit. Later, Barberena (1977) established a biostratigraphic framework for the Santa Maria 153
Formation in which the rocks of the Passo das Tropas Member (bearing fossils of the 154
Dicroidium flora, but not silicified logs) would constitute the intermediate portion of the Santa 155
Maria Formation (Bortoluzzi, 1974; Barberena, 1977), above a basal package of red mudstones 156
dominated by cynodonts and dicynodonts (the Therapsid Assemblage Zone) and below another 157
red mudstones level bearing mainly rhynchosaurs (the Rhynchocephalia Assemblage Zone). 158
Only in 1985 Barberena et al. (1985) detailed the occurrence, in the outcrops mentioned 159
by Andreis et al. (1980) near Candelária Municipality as part of the Caturrita Formation, of a 160
distinct (and younger, regarding to the Santa Maria Formation) vertebrate fauna, composed by 161
the dicynodont Jachaleria candelariensis, the proterochampsid Proterochampsa nodosa, the 162
rhynchosaur ‘Scaphonyx’ sulcognathus (actually Teyumbata sulcognathus Montefeltro; Langer; 163
Schultz, 2010) and Exaeretodon sp. (later formally proposed as E. riograndensis by Abdala; 164
Barberena; Dornelles; 2002). 165
Thus, despite the fact that the lithology of the layers bearing this new fauna (massive, 166
fine sandstones interbedded with red mudstones) does not agree with those described by 167
Bortoluzzi (1974), Andreis et al. (1980) and Barberena et al. (1985) included all those 168
occurrences in a single unit (Caturrita Formation), probably using as a datum their occurrence 169
above the levels dominated by rhynchosaurs. 170
Additionally, Andreis et al. (1982) extended the occurrence of the Caturrita Formation 171
westwards, around the cities of São Pedro do Sul and Mata, based on the occurrence of silicified 172
log-bearing sandstones and subordinate mudstones. Interestingly, Andreis et al. (1982) observed 173
that the proportion between sandstones and mudstones in that area was quite different from that 174
found by Andreis et al. (1980) in Rio Pardo and Santa Cruz regions (where the type-section of 175
the Formation is), but similar to that of the Caturrita Formation in Candelária region (the only 176
ones containing vertebrates, but no silicified logs). Besides, the authors stressed that the 177
silicified logs were the only fossils found in the São Pedro/Mata region and that the age of the 178
package (considering that it belonged to the Caturrita Formation) should be provided not by the 179
silicified logs, but by the fossil reptiles found in Candelária, which indicated a Late 180
Carnian/Early Norian age for the Caturrita Formation. 181
Thereafter, the presence of silicified logs in any outcrop overlying the Santa Maria 182
Formation was used as a field criterion to identify the presence of the “Caturrita Formation”, 183
although in most cases they were only relict fragments at the surface. 184
As a matter of fact, the Santa Maria and Caturrita Formations are considered as part of a 185
Middle-Late Triassic second-order allostratigraphic sequence named the Santa Maria 186
Supersequence (Zerfass et al., 2003). The Supersequence was further divided in (at least) four 187
third-order sequences (Horn et al., 2014), each one beginning with a package dominated by 188
medium- to coarse-grained sandstones with trough cross-stratification at the base 189
(corresponding to the “Passo das Tropas Member”) and red fossiliferous mudstones (the 190
“Alemoa Member”) at the top. Thus the lithologies described by Bortoluzzi (1974) and Andreis 191
et al. (1980) should result from the recurrence of this facies interchange. 192
In regarded to the silicified logs, Faccini (1989) proposed that the fossil logs occurring 193
about 60 km west from Santa Maria City, in São Pedro do Sul and Mata localities, should 194
constitute a distinct sedimentary unit of uncertain age, which could even be Triassic, but surely 195
younger than the levels bearing the Triassic tetrapods in Candelária. Based on this, Faccini 196
(2000) informally coined the name “Mata Sandstone” to refer to these log-bearing layers, 197
naming the “Caturrita Formation” only the Triassic tetrapod-bearing layers from Candelária. 198
Although the work of Faccini (2000) has never been formally published, this proposition has 199
become, in fact, the theoretical framework for subsequent studies on the “Caturrita Formation”, 200
which therefore became only the tetrapod-bearing layers that overly the Santa Maria Formation 201
in Candelária region. 202
Regardless of the silicified logs, the Mata sandstone (sensu Faccini, 2000) is composed 203
of medium- to coarse-grained sandstones with trough cross-stratification and abundant silicified 204
wood logs, thus similar to the “Passo das Tropas Member”, which contains mud chips and 205
abundant extraclasts (mainly by quartz and feldspars), whereas the Mata Sandstones include 206
only intraformational (mud-chip) conglomerates. 207
In this context, considering that (1) the tetrapod-bearing rocks that Andreis et al. (1980) 208
used to determine a Triassic age for the Caturrita Formation are NOT the same as the succession 209
described by Bortoluzzi (1974); (2) the original lithological description of the Caturrita 210
Formation/Member is NOT the one currently used informally; and (3) the current 211
lithostratigraphic definition of the Caturrita Formation is merely informal, the most 212
recommendable procedure would be to use the sequence stratigraphic nomenclature proposed 213
by Zerfass et al. (2003) and Horn et al. (2014), in which the so-called Caturrita Formation 214
would be the upper portion of Candelária Sequence. 215
Due to the significant vertebrate fossil deposits of the Upper Triassic, and since this unit 216
lacks lithostratigraphic formalization, this work aims to provide a detailed facies description and 217
clarify the stratigraphic relations of the former Caturrita Formation, formally proposing a new 218
Formation, called Botucaraí Formation. The choice of a new name has the objective of avoiding 219
mistakes regarding the old propositions. We thus suggest that the former name (Caturrita) is 220
definitely abandoned. 221
GEOLOGICAL SETTING 222
The Paraná Basin is a large, NE-SW-elongated cratonic basin in South America, 223
approximately 1,750 km long and 900 km wide, covering a surface area of around 1,700,000 224
km 2 in Paraguay, Uruguay, Argentina and Brazil (Fig. 2). This basin evolved during the 225
Paleozoic and Mesozoic, with sedimentary package deposited between the Late Ordovician and 226
the Late Cretaceous. Milani (1997) recognized six second-order stratigraphic sequences: Rio 227
Ivaí (Caradocian-Llandoverian), Paraná (Lochkovian-Frasnian), Gondwana I (Westphalian-228
Scythian), Gondwana II (Anisian- Norian), Gondwana III (Neojurassic-Berriasian) and Bauru 229
(Aptian-Maastrichtian). In southern Brazil (Rio Grande do Sul State) the Paraná Basin records a 230
condensed section, with only the Gondwanan sequences cropping out (Gondwana I - Itararé, 231
Guatá and Passa Dois groups, Gondwana II - Pirambóia Formation, Sanga do Cabral and Santa 232
Maria Supersequences, and Gondwana III - Botucatu Formation). 233
The sequence stratigraphic framework proposed by Zerfass (2003) divides the Santa 234
Maria Supersequence in three third-order sequences. Lately, Horn et al. (2014) proposed a 235
fourth sequence (Santa Cruz Sequence, Ladinian), changing the names of the third-order 236
sequences to Pinheiros-Chiniquá (Ladinian-Anysian), Candelária (Carnian) and Mata (Rhaetic). 237
The Santa Maria Formation is the lithostratigraphic correspondent to the Pinheiros-Chiniquá 238
plus the Santa Cruz and the lower Candelária Sequences. In turn, the layers corresponding to 239
the upper Candelária Sequence, formerly called Caturrita Formation, are here assigned to the 240
new Botucaraí Formation. These rocks belong to the Gondwana II Supersequence, which crops 241
out only in Rio Grande do Sul State. 242

THE BOTUCARAÍ FORMATION 244
245
The Botucaraí Formation crops out along approximately 200 km of the Central 246
Depression in Rio Grande do Sul State, from the vicinity of Candelária city westward to Mata 247
city, being mappable on a 1:25000 scale (Fig. 2). 248
Figure 2 249
The stratotype of the Botucaraí Fm. crops out along the BR-287 road near the Botucaraí 250
Hill on the surroundings of Candelária city, Rio Grande do Sul State. In this location, a 251
composite vertical section about fifty meters thick represents all the lithotypes that comprise the 252
Botucaraí Formation. Moreover, these outcrops contain in situ vertebrate fossils that corroborate 253
the Triassic age of the proposed Formation. The two most representative outcrops of the 254
lithotypes are detailed below. 255
The first outcrop is located at the foot of Botucaraí Hill, on a road cut along BR-287 256
(UTM coordinates: 22J 321859mS and 6715100mW). This outcrop is widely known among 257
Brazilian paleontologists (the Botucaraí outcrop) due to its fossil content and easy access. The 258
outcrop is composed of a succession of centimetric to decimetric tabular layers of fine- to very 259
fine-grained, massive sandstones, interlayered with millimetric to centimetric layers of red 260
mudstones (Fig. 3). An amalgamated massive, fine-sandstone body occurs at the upper part of 261
the outcrop. 262
Figure 3 263
The second outcrop is also located along BR-287 road (coordinates: 22J 320750mN and 264
6713692mW), and it is known as the Sesmaria do Pinhal outcrop. It comprises metric, 265
amalgamated layers of fine-grained, massive sandstones, with erosive basal contact and mud 266
intraclasts along the base, as well as dispersed within the bodies (Fig. 4). Subordinately, 267
horizontally-bedded and trough cross-stratified sandstones and massive red mudstones also 268
occur. These rocks have been studied by many authors, including Faccini (2000), Zerfass et al. 269
(2003) and Da Rosa (2005), who interpreted them as fluvial deposits correlated to the informal 270
Caturrita Formation. 271
Figure 4 272
The outcrops in the type section attest that, unlike the Caturrita Member proposed by 273
Bortoluzzi (1974), characterized by a dominance of trough cross-bedded, medium-grained 274
sandstones, the Botucaraí Formation is mostly composed of massive, fine-grained sandstones, 275
with subordinate horizontally-laminated and trough cross-stratified sandstones described above. 276
The lower boundary of the Botucaraí Formation is an abrupt contact or erosive 277
unconformity with the red mudstones of the Alemoa Member (Santa Maria Formation). The 278
upper boundary is either a concordant unconformity with the Juro-Cretaceous Botucatu 279
Formation, an erosive unconformity with the Mata sandstones, or an erosive unconformity with 280
rocks of probable Jurassic age, as described in detail below (Fig. 5). 281
Figure 5 282
In one outcrop in the surroundings of Faxinal do Soturno city (coordinates: 22J 283
262823mN e 6727662mW), the massive, fine-grained sandstones with vertebrate fossils typical 284
of the Botucaraí Formation are unconformably overlain by a Jurassic package (Fig. 6). The 285
unconformity is characterized by an abrupt facies shift, where massive, fine sandstones with 286
paleosols at the top (characterized by variegated texture and purplish colors) are juxtaposed by 287
red, fossiliferous shales and siltstones. The contact between these lithotypes is a 288
paleotopographic surface with at least half a meter of relief, locally very cemented by calcite 289
(Fig. 6B, C). 290
Figure 6 291
In the red mudrocks overlying the unconformity, Rohn et al. (2014) described new 292
conchostracan species, Nothocarapacestheria soturnensis. This genus has taxonomic affinity 293
with Jurassic genera from the Transantarctic Mountains identified as Australesteria sp., very 294
similar to Jurassic specimens from the Congo Basin. Barboni & Dutra (2013) described 295
reproductive structures (Williamsonia sp.) and branches from Benetittalles plants associated 296
with autochthonous conifer logs and branches remains (Pagiophyllum sp., Dutra & Faccini, 297
2002) in this unit, suggesting ages younger than the Triassic by correlation with genera of 298
Argentinian basins. Additionally, Silva et al. (2012) described Eubrontes sp., a large-size (11 299
cm x 22 cm) tridactyl footprint attributed to large theropod dinosaurs in this package. Since this 300
type of dinosaur footprints is not common in the Triassic, it also suggests a younger age. Hence 301
the paleontological content of the package overlying the unconformity at the top of the 302
Botucaraí Formation in this locality attributes a Jurassic age for these rocks. So far it is unclear 303
whether or not these Jurassic rocks are mappable, since they have been identified only in this 304
outcrop. However, with time and further work, it is possible that a Jurassic unit is proposed, as 305
suggested by Rohn et al. (2014). 306
The maximum thickness of the newly proposed Botucaraí Formation is based on field 307
data collected by the authors and drill-core information provided by Machado (2005). In that 308
work, the author estimates the maximum thickness of the (former) Caturrita Formation in 309
hydrological wells as around fifty meters, approximately the same thickness of the measured 310
vertical sections in the type-section outcrops. 311
PALEONTOLOGICAL CONTENT, STRATIGRAPHICAL POSITIONING AND AGE 312
The dating of the Botucaraí Formation is based on its vertebrate fossil content, with a 313
diverse fauna that includes dinosaurs, advanced cynodonts and dicynodonts. The presence of the 314
dicynodont Jachaleria candelariensis (Araújo; Gonzaga, 1980) indicates a Late Triassic age to 315
this unit by its correlation with J. colorata, that occurs at the base of Los Colorados Formation, 316
in Argentina, where paleomagnetic data indicates a Norian age (227.5-215 Ma, Santi Malnis et 317
al. 2011). Silicified logs were not found in these layers, corroborating the observations of 318
Faccini (2000). Besides Jachaleria, the Botucaraí Formation includes the presence of the 319
prosauropod Unaysaurus tolentinoi (Leal, et al. 2003), and the theropod (sensu Langer et al. 320
2009) Guaibasaurus candelariensis (Bonaparte; Ferigolo; Ribeiro, 1999). In addition to these 321
dinosaurs, these beds also yielded the dinosauriform Sacisaurus agudoensis Ferigolo; Langer, 322
2006, an indeterminate phytosaur (Kischlat; Lucas 2003), isolated teeth of archosaurs 323
(Dornelles, 1990) and a stereospondyl amphibian (Dias-da-Silva et al. 2009). The most striking 324
paleontological feature in this unit, however, is the presence of a diversified fauna of small-325
sized (<10 cm) vertebrates that includes the procolophonid Soturnia caliodon (Cisneros; 326
Schultz, 2003), the sphenodontid Clevosaurus brasiliensis (Bonaparte; Sues, 2006), the 327
lepidosaur Cargninia enigmatica (Bonaparte et al., 2010), the pterosaur(?) Faxinalipterus 328
minima (Bonaparte et al., 2010), and five taxa of advanced, non-mammaliaform cynodonts 329
(sensu Abdala 2007). Among these, Riograndia guaibensis (Bonaparte; Ferigolo; Ribeiro, 2001) 330
was the first one reported, followed by Brasilodon quadrangularis, Brasilitherium 331
riograndensis (Bonaparte, et al., 2003), Irajatherium hernandezi (Martinelli, et al., 2005), and 332
Minicynodon maieri (Bonaparte et al. 2010; (Soares, Schultz, Horn, 2011). 333
The widespread presence of Riograndia guaibensis in the Botucaraí Formation was 334
utilized to propose a biozone (Riograndia Assemblage Zone, Soares et al. 2011) to that tetrapod 335
fauna that allowed the correlation of distinct outcrops with no lateral continuity, and thus the 336
biostratigraphic dating of these Upper Triassic rocks. 337

CONCLUSIONS 339
The usage of the name “Caturrita Formation” became a stratigraphic problem in the 340
Triassic of southern Brazil due to the lack of formalization and utilization of this informal name 341
for a variety of lithotypes for a long time. Based on field and literature data, this work proposes 342
the complete abandonment of the Caturrita Formation, and the formal proposition of the 343
Botucaraí Formation, with well-defined stratigraphic relations and lithologies. The newly 344
proposed unit refers to the rock package that overlies the Santa Maria Formation, containing a 345
typical association of fossil tetrapods (Riograndia AZ) of Neotriassic age. Its type section crops 346
out at the base of the Botucaraí Hill, in Candelaria city, and comprises dominantly fine-grained, 347
massive sandstones with mud intraclasts, and subordinately, horizontally-bedded and trough 348
cross-stratified sandstones and massive red mudstones. The Botucaraí Formation abruptly 349
overlies the red mudrocks of the Alemoa Member and is overlain by the Juro-Cretaceous 350
Botucatu Formation, or locally by a Jurassic unit yet to be defined. The existence of Jurassic 351
layers above the Botucaraí Formation is based on paleontological and stratigraphic data, but its 352
occurrence is still too restricted to allow the formalization of a new stratigraphic unit. 353

ABSTRACT 26
Global climate in the Middle to Late Triassic is considered mainly semi-arid with strong 27
seasonal variation. This climatic setting propitiates the formation of climatically-28
controlled depositional systems such as dust deposits and ephemeral rivers. Loess 29
deposits are increasingly being recognized within pre-quaternary sedimentary 30
sequences. Until recently, the lack of criteria for loess identification rendered difficult 31
the interpretation of ancient deposits. The Santa Maria Supersequence was deposited in 32
the Middle to Late Triassic and still lacks a full understanding of its depositional 33
systems. This work aims to characterize the depositional systems of this time interval in 34
the Paraná Basin and discuss their paleoclimatic significance through the use of field, 35
chemical and paleontologic data. The depositional system comprises four facies 36
associations: braided river, dry mudflat, distal sheetflood and sheet delta. Dry mudflat 37
facies association dominates in the Pinheiros-Chiniquá and Santa Cruz Sequences, and 38
sheetflood delta facies association occurs only in the Candelária Sequence. Evidence for 39
loess deposits includes the absence of floodplain feeding channels, thick, structureless 40
siltstone bodies, the overwhelming dominance of grain-size mode in 0.0031mm and age 41
dispersion of dated zircons. Throughout the Santa Maria Supersequence, the chemical 42
index of alteration indicates semi-arid climate, in agreement with global-scale 43
paleoclimatic conditions. However, during the Carnian the abundance of calcrete 44
decreased and the occurrence of aquatic and semi-aquatic fauna increased, implying an 45
increase in humidity in this interval. Other fossiliferous basins in Gondwana recorded 46
the same short-lived, humid event. The humid peak may be associated with the Carnian 47
"Wet Intemezzo", related with the development of the Wrangellian large igneous 48
province (LIP). 49

INTRODUCTION 55
Global climate in the Middle to Late Triassic is considered arid to semi-arid in interior 56
Gondwana, with intense evaporation through most of the year (Sellwood and Valdes, 57
2006). Climates like these favor the deposition of eolian and ephemeral fluvial 58
sediments. Loess, or terrestrial eolian silt, covers a substantial area of mid-to high-59
latitude surface today, and it is recognized as a high-fidelity archive of climate change 60
and atmosphere circulation for the Plio-Pleistocene (Soreghan et al. 2008; Muhs and 61
Bettis, 2003). Its deposition is commonly associated with arid to semi-arid climate 62
settings, near desert areas or in orogeny shadow zones (Pye, 1995). 63
Loess deposits are increasingly being recognized within pre-quaternary sedimentary 64
sequences. Until recently, the lack of criteria for loess interpretation rendered difficult 65
the interpretation of ancient deposits. Soreghan et al. (2007) reinterpreted some 66
floodplain deposits in the continental U.S. as Paleozoic loess deposits, providing criteria 67
to differentiate loess deposits in ancient settings. Following that work, some other 68
deposits formerly interpreted as floodplain were re-interpreted as loess deposits, mainly 69
in the middle Permian (Foster et al. 2014; Sweet et al.2013). 70
The Santa Maria Supersequence (Zerfass et al. 2003) comprises Middle to Late Triassic 71
deposits in the Paraná Basin, correlative to southern and northern Pangaea deposits 72
(Schultz et al. 2000; Lucas, 1998) that bear many sedimentary proxies indicative of arid 73
to semi-arid conditions (Holz, 2015). The presence of early dinosaur and early 74
4
Mammaliamorpha fossils makes this Supersequence important for the understanding of 75
life and climate in southern Gondwana during the early Mesozoic. However, several 76
doubts about the depositional systems in this Supersequence, and how they vary in the 77
Late Triassic in response to climate and base-level changes, still persist. Recently some 78
authors have attributed the sedimentary changes and paleontological overturn recorded 79
in various Triassic basins to an unusual wet interval occurred around 233-227 Ma, due 80
to the eruption of a large igneous province (LIP), the Wrangellia LIP, which is now 81
accreted to western North America (Greene et al. 2010; Ogg, 2015). 82
This paper aims at describing the presence of climate-sensitive sediments (calcrete, 83
loess and ephemeral fluvial) of the Santa Maria Supersequence in the Paraná Basin, 84
discussing the depositional environments and paleoclimate of this unit and how it 85
relates to Gondwana climate. 86
GEOLOGICAL SETTING 87
The Santa Maria Supersequence is the Triassic deposits in the Paraná Basin, a large, 88
NE-SW-elongated intracratonic basin in South America with a surface area of 89
approximately 1,700,000 km 2 in Paraguay, Uruguay, Argentina and Brazil (Fig. 1 A). 90
This basin evolved during the Paleozoic and Mesozoic, comprising a sedimentary 91
package deposited between the Late Ordovician and the Late Cretaceous. 92
Sequence stratigraphic framework for Triassic beds in the Paraná Basin was first 93
proposed by Zerfass et al. (2003), dividing the package in three third-order sequences. 94
Lately, Horn et al. (2014) included a forth sequence (Santa Cruz Sequence, 95
Santacruzodon Assemblage Zone(AZ), Carnian), changing the names of the previous 96
third-order sequences to Pinheiros-Chiniquá (Dinodontosaurus AZ, Ladinian-Carnian), 97
Candelária ( Hyperodapedon and Riograndia AZ, Carnian-Norian) and Mata (Rhaetic) 98
5
(Soares et al. 2011). The ages in the Santa Maria Supersequence are based on 99
biostratigraphic correlation with Argentinian fauna. The Santa Cruz Sequence was 100
recently dated by U-Pb in detrital zircons as 236.1Ma (Phillip et al. 2016). The Santa 101
Maria Supersequence is equivalent to the Triassic Gondwana II Supersequence of 102
Milani and Ramos (1998), which occurs only in southern Brazil. 103
Lithostratigraphically the Sequences Pinheiros-Chiniquá (PCS), Santa Cruz (SCS) and 104
Candelária (CS) are attributed to the Santa Maria Formation (Gordon Jr, 1947). The 105
Santa Maria Formation is composed of the basal Passo das Tropas Member, with 106
conglomeratic to coarse-grained sandstones with abundant mud clasts and locally plant 107
and insect remains, and the top Alemoa Member, with red-colored massive mudstones 108
with occasional stratification and abundant vertebrate fossil remains (Zerfass et al. 109
2003). In fact, each one of the third order sequences (PCS, SCS and CS) begins with 110
conglomeratic deposits that are followed by fine grained layers. The upper portion of 111
CS is attributed to Caturrita Formation (Andreis et al, 1980). Despite the recent work on 112
sequence stratigraphy focusing on the stratigraphic evolution of the Triassic package, 113
the paleontological community relies heavily on the lithostratigraphic nomenclature due 114
to the occurrence of vertebrates consistently in the red mudstones of the Alemoa 115
Member. Since this work aims at discussing the depositional environments and their 116
relation with the vertebrate fossils, facies description and further discussion will dwell 117
on the lithostratigraphic units. 118
